intro: Lathyrus laxiflorus var. glabratus, commonly known as the glabrous bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring slender, upright stems covered in small, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale pink, often blooming in late spring to early summer. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it a suitable addition to rock gardens or dry gardens. Due to its ornamental value and adaptability, it is sometimes cultivated in horticultural settings.
